unnormalised: I'm confused, are all doctors called 'Dr.'? Like, do dentists get offended if you call them Mr. or Ms.? It's all so formal!
normalised: I am confused, are all doctors called 'Doctor'? Like, do dentists get offended if you call them Mister or Miss? It is all so formal!

unnormalised: Seriously though, it’s a bit more nuanced than that. ‘Dr.’ is generally for someone with a doctorate. In the medical field, that usually means an MD (Doctor of Medicine) or a DO (Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine). Dentists typically have a DDS (Doctor of Dental Surgery) or a DMD (Doctor of Dental Medicine). Legally, they *can* use 'Dr.' and generally do. Imagine going to Dr. Iyer for a root canal and calling her "Ms." Iyer, she might think you're questioning her credentials, or worse, she'll pre-pone your appointment to next year!
normalised: Seriously though, it's a bit more nuanced than that. 'Doctor' is generally for someone with a doctorate. In the medical field, that usually means an M-D (Doctor of Medicine) or a D-O (Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine). Dentists typically have a D-D-S (Doctor of Dental Surgery) or a D-M-D (Doctor of Dental Medicine). Legally, they can use 'Doctor' and generally do. Imagine going to Doctor Iyer for a root canal and calling her "Miss" Iyer, she might think you are questioning her credentials, or worse, she will pre-pone your appointment to next year!

unnormalised: But then it gets even *more* confusing! We've got 'Prof.' for professors at medical colleges, 'Asst. Prof.' for assistant professors and 'Assoc. Prof' for Associate Professors. What about those fancy specialists? Is it 'Dr. Gupta, Cardiologist', or 'Cardiologist Gupta, Dr.'? And what about the poor Ayush doctors? Are they Dr. Sharma (BAMS)? It's a title-palooza!
normalised: But then it gets even more confusing! We have got 'Professor' for professors at medical colleges, 'Assistant Professor' for assistant professors and 'Associate Professor' for Associate Professors. What about those fancy specialists? Is it 'Doctor Gupta, Cardiologist', or 'Cardiologist Gupta, Doctor'? And what about the poor Ayush doctors? Are they Doctor Sharma (B-A-M-S)? It's a title-palooza!

unnormalised: Honestly, just stick with 'Dr.' unless you know their specific qualifications and *want* to impress them (or subtly imply they aren't a *real* doctor, if you're into that kind of passive-aggressive dental appointment). A little respect (and a genuine smile) will go a long way, even if you accidentally call Dr. Khan, BDS "Mr." Khan. Just don't expect a discount on your next filling!
normalised: Honestly, just stick with 'Doctor' unless you know their specific qualifications and want to impress them (or subtly imply they are not a real doctor, if you are into that kind of passive-aggressive dental appointment). A little respect (and a genuine smile) will go a long way, even if you accidentally call Doctor Khan, B-D-S "Mister" Khan. Just don't expect a discount on your next filling!
